ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: n/a

Understanding how practice gets translated into theory, and wrestling with the implications of re-applying theory to practice. The challenges of identifying and addressing problems in K-12 education in the United States, perspectives on education reform and theories of change in education.
how to break down large educational issues into both root causes, factors and possible solutions
Faculty development processes, understanding of the complex issues behind the scenes in K-12 education.
Learned about US education as an organization, how to think about change in a system, organizational theory, case studies about education reform

I learned so much from this course, and it's not even necessarily about the content, but about the problem solving, leadership and collaboration skills I got to practice. One of the most hands-on, engaging, immersive classes I've taken at Yale (if not the most). The project is where you get to practice all of these skills in depth, and Professor Lemons does a great job at making the final presentation feel high stakes because of the effort that goes into planning it and the panelists he invites -- so there's a lot of intrinsic motivation at work in this course. Every assignment felt important and intellectually engaging. Readings were super interesting.
Understanding education as a leadership system, efficiently yet comprehensively analyzing theories of change and improvement paradigms on the basis of educational theory.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: n/a

Strengths: relevant and interesting readings, great cases
Weaknesses: lack of direction in final project made it difficult to properly narrow scope

strengths: engagement. one of the most engaged seminars i have ever taken at Yale. 
weaknesses: semester project and connection to class was a little hard to see at times. wish there was more in class support for the project.
Phenomenal course!
heavy workload, but very interesting and relevant material.

Strengths: engaging and well-organized discussions, well-organized class and good use of the entire class time, small class and smaller group discussions and projects foster genuine relationships with classmates, lots of classmates were not undergrads (had medical doctors as classmates and MBA student/former teacher)-- enriching to hear from diverse educational backgrounds

Weaknesses: honestly, none come to mind

Strengths: Incredibly engaging, great feedback throughout, interesting readings that are not too heavy, weekly memos with in depth feedback, feedback from peers, immersive class discussions, professor treats you with intellectual respect.

Weaknesses: honestly none.
Strengths: exceptional teaching and practice, great readings, high but rewarding workload balance; Weaknesses: none

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: n/a

Absolutely. Professor Lemons is a wonderful instructor and the breadth of information that you cover in educational leadership, educational issues, and theories of change is very interesting. Learnings about driving change in education is broadly applicable outside of the field.

most definitely. an engaging seminar that allows you to tackle social-educational issues thorough class discussions, mind mapping, case studies. the 1h50 minutes on Wednesdays night felt shorter than some of my 50 minute lectures - it is incredible.
Yes!
take this class especially if you're an EDST student! I learned so much about the parts of our larger ED system and how to think about reform and change in education
YES, honestly even if you're not super interested in education, you learn about leadership, collaboration and problem solving in this course more than anything. So would highly recommend to anyone.
Absolutely, with no hesitation. Take this class if you're interested in leadership as a theory and practice, even more so if you're keen on learning about the gaps and opportunities in education.
